1998 ). Furthermore, MCs have been reported to be responsible
for oxidative stress induced in many species: mice ( Gehringer,
2004 ); rat ( Moreno et al., 2003 ); and aquatic organisms such as
crab ( Pinho et al., 2005 ) and ﬁsh ( Mourente et al., 2002; Li et
al., 2005; Jos et al., 2005; Cazenave et al., 2006; Prieto et al.,2006 ).
As a result of the oxidative stress caused, ﬁsh, like many
other vertebrates, try to reduce the damage using the antioxidantdefence system. This includes radical scavenging enzymes: cata-lase (CAT) and superoxide dismutase (SOD) acting on hydrogenperoxide (H
2O2) and superoxide (O 2•−), respectively, and glu-
tathione peroxidase (GPx), which scavenges H 2O2and lipid
hydroperoxides. Associated enzymes include glutathione reduc-tase (GR), which acts to maintain levels of reduced glutathione(Halliwell and Gutteridge, 1984 ). Also, the defence system
includes many other antioxidants such as glutathione (GSH),vitamins E, C and A, carotenes and ubiquinol
10(Wilhelm,
1996 ). MCs have been reported to induce a marked decrease
of GSH contents in hepatocytes of common carp ( Li et al.,
2003 ).
Tilapias ( Oreochromis niloticus sp.) have been extensively
employed to study the antioxidant response to many toxic sub-stances (metals, herbicides, etc.). In this way, Almeida et al.
(2002) used antioxidant enzymes, SOD and GPx, as biomarkers
in liver and muscle from tilapia exposed to in vivo cadmium con-tamination. Further, Basha and Rani (2003) reported increases
of SOD, xanthine oxidase (XO), CAT and GPx activities in liverand kidney of tilapia exposed to sublethal concentrations of cad-mium chloride. Alteration of CAT activity was reported by Atli
et al. (2006) in tilapia liver, kidney, gill, intestine and brain upon
metal exposure. Peixoto et al. (2006) exposed tilapia to the her-
bicide oxyﬂuorfen showing increased GR and SOD activitiesin liver. The effect of another herbicide (2,4-dichlorophenoxyacetic acid dimethyl amine salt) and an insecticide (azin-phosmethyl) were investigated in hepatic antioxidant enzymeactivities and lipid peroxidation in tilapia ( Oruc¸ and ¨Uner, 2000 ).
Previous investigations of our research group have shown that
cyanobacterial material containing MCs is able to induce oxida-tive stress in tilapia ﬁsh when they are exposed sub-chronically(14 and 21 days) by oral route to an equivalent of 60.0 /H9262g
MC-LR/ﬁsh/day ( Jos et al., 2005 ). We have also shown that
pure toxins MC-LR and MC-RR induce a differential oxida-tive stress response in tilapia exposed intraperitoneally ( Prieto
et al., 2006 ). Taking these results into account, the aim of the
present study was to investigate the response of the activities ofthe antioxidant enzymes SOD, CAT, GPx, and also the activityof GR, the enzyme reducing oxidized glutathione (GSSG) to itsreduced state (GSH), and the lipid peroxidation status in liver,kidney and gills of tilapia ﬁsh acutely exposed by oral routeto a single dose of cyanobacterial material containing 120.0 /H9262g
MC-LR/ﬁsh. The ﬁsh were sacriﬁced 24 or 72 h after the expo-sure. Additionally, the protein oxidation and the MCs contenthave been determined in the liver of the ﬁsh. This investigationallows us to determine how the antioxidant status of tilapia ﬁshvaries with time in the experimental conditions used. From theresults it is possible to evaluate the recovery from the damageinduced.2. Materials and methods
2.1. Experimental set up and acclimation of ﬁsh
Male O. niloticus sp. (Nile tilapia, Perciformes: Cichlidae),
average weight 50 ±8 g, were obtained from a ﬁsh hatchery
in C´ordoba. Fish were transferred to the laboratory where they
were held in aquaria (eight individuals/aquarium) with 96 L offresh water. Exposure to chlorine was minimized by ﬁlling thetanks at least 3 days before the ﬁsh were introduced. The aquariawere also set up with continuous system of water ﬁltrationand aeration (Eheim Liberty 150 and Bio-Espumador cartridges(Bio-Espumador)) and the temperature varied between 20 and24
◦C. Dissolved oxygen values were maintained between
6.5 and 7.5 mg/L. Mean values for additional parameters ofwater quality were: pH 7.6 ±0.3, conductivity 287 /H9262S/cm, Ca
2+
0.60 mM and Mg2+0.3 mM. Fish were fed with commercial ﬁsh
food and were acclimatized for 15 days before the beginning ofthe experiments.
2.2. Collection of Microcystis aeruginosa strain culture
and determination of cyanobacterial toxins
Lyophilized M. aeruginosa isolated strain culture was kindly
supplied by Dr Susana Franca (Lisboa, Portugal). MCs con-tained were extracted from dried cell material using the methodofMoreno et al. (2004) . The lyophilized cells (50 mg) were
extracted three times with 10 mL 0.1 M acetic acid and 20 mLof a mixture of methanol:chloroform (1:1 v/v). The cell suspen-sion was sonicated in an ultra-sound bath for 15 min, stirred for30 min at room temperature, and then centrifuged at 4500 ×g
for 15 min. The upper aqueous phases were combined and con-centrated in a rotary evaporator. The residue was re-suspendedin 0.5 mL methanol for chromatographic separation.
The LC system used to analyse the toxin contents was a Varian
9012 equipped with a Varian ProStar 330 Diode Array Detector.Chromatographic data was processed with a Star Chromatog-raphy Workstation (Varian Technologies). Chromatographicseparation of MCs was performed according to Moreno et al.
(2004) on a 250 mm ×4.6 mm i.d., 5 /H9262m, LiChrosphere C18
column purchased from Merck (Darmstadt, Germany).
Microcystin standards were supplied by Cyanobiotech (Ger-
many). Standard solutions of microcystins MC-LR, MC-YRand MC-RR were prepared in methanol (500 /H9262g/mL) and
diluted as required with methanol for use as working solutions(0.5–5.0 mg/L of each toxin). Only MC-LR was identiﬁed inthe cyanobacterial cell extracts analysed and the peak area ofthe MC-LR standard solution was applied for quantiﬁcation.The concentration of MCs obtained from lyophilised cells was1350/H9262g/g MC-LR.
2.3. Exposure
Tilapia ﬁsh in two test aquaria ( n= 8) were fed with commer-
cial ﬁsh food plus lyophilised cyanobacterial cells, containing1350/H9262g/g MC-LR. Cyanobacterial cells were fed to the ﬁsh by
manually crushing a mixture of both components (ﬁsh food andA.I. Prieto et al. / Aquatic T oxicology 84 (2007) 337–345 339
toxic cells) in a mortar followed by sonication. This procedure
resulted in small sticky pellets and was designed to replicate thetype of exposure that may occur when a bloom of cyanobac-teria undergoes lysis under ﬁeld conditions releasing its MCcontents. The pellets were placed in the tank and drifted tothe bottom for the ﬁsh to take. It was ensured that all the pel-lets were eaten within an hour. The amount of commercial ﬁshfood administered per ﬁsh was 0.3 g/day and the quantity ofcyanobacterial cells was selected in order to dose approximately120.0 /H9262g MC-LR/ﬁsh (determined from HPLC analysis). After-
wards, the ﬁsh were sacriﬁced at two different periods of time, 24and 72 h.
Two control groups of ﬁsh ( n= 8) were administered only
the commercial ﬁsh food during the whole experiment and weresacriﬁced in two different periods of time, 24 and 72 h, at thesame time as exposed ﬁsh.
2.4. Extraction and determination of MCs
MCs in the livers of each group of ﬁsh were extracted accord-
ing to Moreno et al. (2005a) . Fish tissues were homogenized
with 85% methanol twice, the extract once evaporated wasre-dissolved in 0.25 mL of 100% methanol. Afterwards thisextract was dried by sterilized air and percolated in PBS buffer(1/2 to 1/3) to get a methanol concentration under 15% (v/v).MC content was determined by enzyme-linked immunosor-bent assay (ELISA) (Envirogard
R, Strategic Diagnostic Inc.,
Newark, USA) according to Moreno et al. (2004) .
2.5. Preparation of post-mitochondrial supernatant (PMS)
At the end of the experiment, the ﬁsh were anaesthetized by
immersion in 50 mg/L tricaine methane sulphonate (MS-222)solution for 5–10 min before they were killed by transection ofthe spinal cord. Both control and toxin-exposed ﬁsh were anaes-thetized in the same manner,which excludes a speciﬁc effect ofthe product in the stress-related research. The liver, kidney andgills were removed, weighed, rinsed with ice-cold saline andkept at −85
◦C until analysis. The tissues were homogenized in
chilled Tris buffer (100 mM, pH 7.8; 1:10 w/v) using an Ultra-Turrax
®tissue homogenizer. The homogenates were centrifuged
at 10,500 ×g for 20 min at 4◦C to obtain the post-mitochondrial
supernatant (PMS) for various biochemical analysis.
2.6. Lipid peroxidation
Lipid peroxidation products were quantiﬁed by the thio-
barbituric acid (TBA) method ( Esterbauer and Cheeseman,
1990 ). End lipid peroxidation products react with TBA reagent
under acidic conditions to generate a pink coloured product.Brieﬂy, the homogenized tissue (0.5 mL), previously treatedwith 25 /H9262L of butylhydroxytoluene 1% mass/vol in glacial
acetic, was mixed with 0.2 mL of sodium laurylsulphate (8%),1 mL of acetic acid (20% vol/vol) and 1 mL of 0.8% thiobar-bituric acid. This mixture was then heated at 95
◦C for 30 min.
The resulting chromogen was extracted with 3 mL of n-butyl
alcohol and, after centrifugation (1500 ×gfor 10 min), theabsorbance of the organic phase was determined at 532 nm.
1,1,3,3-Tetramethoxypropan was used as a standard. Valueswere presented as nmol TBARS/g tissue.
2.7. Protein carbonyl content
We followed the method described by Levine et al. (1990) .
Brieﬂy, two test tubes of 1.0 mL containing 30 and 60 /H9262L
homogenized sample, respectively, ( ≈10–20 mg protein) were
taken. 0.5 mL of fresh 10 mM 2,4-dinitrophenylhydrazine(DNPH) prepared in 2 M HCl was added to the tubes, and thecontents were mixed thoroughly and incubated at room temper-ature for 1 h. The tubes were shaken intermittently every 15 min.Then 0.5 mL of 20% TCA (w/v) was added to both tubes, whichwere centrifuged at 11,000 ×g for 3 min to obtain the protein
pellet. The supernatant was carefully aspirated and discarded.Finally, the precipitates were washed three times with 0.5 mLof ethanol:ethyl acetate (1:1, v/v) to remove unreacted DNPHand lipid remnants. The ﬁnal protein pellet was dissolved in0.6 mL of 6 M guanidine hydrochloride and incubated overnightat room temperature. 3. Results
3.1. Effect of cyanobacterial cells on lipid peroxidation
The liver was the most affected organ, showing a signiﬁ-
cant 3.6-fold induction of lipid peroxidation in ﬁsh exposed tocyanobacterial cells and sacriﬁced at 24 h. At this time point,kidney and gills maintained basal values for the LPO ( Fig. 1 ).
However, after 72 h all the organs studied showed a signiﬁcantincrease of lipid peroxidation in comparison with control groups.Comparing 24 and 72 h LPO results, a signiﬁcant increase wasobserved in kidney (1.8-fold) and gills (1.4-fold) but a 1.2-folddecrease in liver.

4. Discussion
MCs have been reported to cause toxic effects, including
oxidative stress, in ﬁsh when the toxins are applied by oral route342 A.I. Prieto et al. / Aquatic T oxicology 84 (2007) 337–345

(Jos et al., 2005; Li et al., 2005 ), by immersion ( Cazenave et al.,
2006 ), or intraperitoneally ( Prieto et al., 2006 ). Regarding the
oral route, Jos et al. (2005) showed higher toxic effects when
ﬁsh were fed with crushed cyanobacterial cells (released toxins)than when the ﬁsh were exposed to non crushed cells. In viewof these results, this kind of administration was chosen in thepresent work in order to guarantee as large effects as possible.
Many experimental studies have been conducted to document
that cyanobacterial exposure through the gastrointestinal systemcan cause toxic effects on many ﬁsh species such as commoncarp ( Fischer and Dietrich, 2000 ), silver carp ( Xie et al., 2007 ),
loach ( Li et al., 2005 ), rainbow trout ( Tencalla and Dietrich,
1996 ), tilapia ( Mohamed et al., 2003; Mohamed and Hussein,

2006 ). However, studies focussing on acute oral effects, partic-
ularly on oxidative stress, in the ﬁrst days after exposure are stillvery scarce, although Ernst et al. (2006) studied the oral toxicity
ofPlanktothrix rubescens in European whiteﬁsh, showing toxic
effects from 24 h after exposure.
The current study revealed that the most affected organ with
regard to the antioxidant enzyme status was the kidney, whereasthe liver was the most affected organ with regard to the lipid per-oxidation. No signiﬁcant changes were observed in gills apartfrom an increase in lipid peroxidation of ﬁsh sacriﬁced 72 h afterexposure. The alterations observed in the liver can be explainedA.I. Prieto et al. / Aquatic T oxicology 84 (2007) 337–345 343
with the afﬁnity of MCs to this organ. Fischer et al. (2005)
explained hepatotoxicity of MCs by their transport mediatedby members of the organic anion transporting polypeptide, asuperfamily of membrane transporters that are expressed in hep-atocytes and in the blood–brain barrier. This can explain whyLPO was altered in liver already at 24 h, whereas in kidney andgills the effect was signiﬁcant only after 72 h.
In addition to the liver damage, MCs can also affect other
organs in ﬁsh such as kidney (rainbow trout, Kotak et al., 1996 ;
tilapias, Molina et al., 2005 ), gills (common carp, Rabergh et al.,
1991 ), intestine (tilapia, Molina et al., 2005 ), heart (brown trout,
Best et al., 2001 ; loach, Liu et al., 2002 ), and brain ( Cazenave
et al., 2006 ). The most affected organs in ﬁsh are liver and
kidney, with hepatocyte dissociation and degeneration in liverand dilation of Bowman’s capsule in kidney ( Zurawell et al.,
2005 ). Indeed, similar ﬁndings were observed in histopatholog-
ical studies performed in our laboratory in liver and kidney oftilapia exposed sub-chronically to toxic cyanobacterial blooms,where only slight histopathological changes were detected ingills ( Molina et al., 2005 ). All these reports agree with the present
results, which show larger alterations in the enzyme activitiesand lipid peroxidation of liver and kidney than of gills. More-over, no gill patholology was observed in the oral toxicity studyof the MC-containing cyanobacterium P . rubescens in European
whiteﬁsh ( Coregonus lavaretus )(Ernst et al., 2006 ). In contrast
with these results, Cazenave et al. (2006) demonstrated alter-
ations of antioxidant enzyme activities (GR and GPx) in gillsof ﬁsh ( Corydoras paleatus ) exposed to MC-RR by immersion.
Thus, the exposure route inﬂuences the location of the majortoxic effects induced by MCs.
The alterations in antioxidant enzyme activities detected were
also observed in previous studies performed in our laboratoryin which tilapia were orally exposed to cyanobacterial cells dur-ing 14 and 21 days ( Jos et al., 2005 ), and intraperitoneally to
an acute dose of pure MCs ( Prieto et al., 2006 ). The largest
changes in the present work were observed in general for CATand SOD activities in the liver and the kidney, as in previousstudies performed. Li et al. (2005) also reported a greater vari-
ation of SOD and CAT activities in comparison to GPx in theliver when loaches were orally exposed to a Microcystis bloom
for 28 days. However, no effect was found on lipid peroxidation.Nevertheless, although Jos et al. (2005) showed an increase in
the antioxidant enzymes studied, in the present work a decreaseas compared to controls is observed. This might be due to thedifferent exposure periods and MC doses used in the experi-ments: in the experiments of Jos et al. (2005) ﬁsh were exposed
to 60.0 /H9262g MC-LR/ﬁsh/day for 21 days, whereas in the present
study a single dose of 120.0 /H9262g MC-LR/ﬁsh was given and ﬁsh
sacriﬁced 24 or 72 h after the exposure. The higher MC dosemay damage the enzyme proteins while lower dose, given for alonger period of time, may induce a defensive response. In fact,rats exposed intraperitoneally to an acute dose of pure MC-LRshowed a signiﬁcant decrease in the antioxidant enzymes (CAT,SOD, GR and GPx) ( Moreno et al., 2005b ).
Lipid peroxidation is particularly important for aquatic ani-
mals since they normally contain greater amounts of highlyunsaturated fatty acids (HUFA) than other species ( Huang etal., 2003 ). It must be pointed out that lipid and protein oxi-
dation in liver are higher after 24 h and diminish signiﬁcantlyafter 72 h, indicating that the tilapia defence system was initiallyoverwhelmed. Pinho et al. (2005) also reported an increase of
both parameters in the hepatopancreas of crabs orally exposedto MCs. The recovery of the damage could be explained, inpart, by the increased activities of CAT and GR observed in theliver of ﬁshes sacriﬁced after 72 h compared to those sacriﬁcedafter 24 h. However, the activities of antioxidant enzymes stud-ied in the kidney and gills as well as SOD and GPx activities inliver do not show a clear functional recovery, possibly because alonger time is required for the de novo synthesis of proteins. Inthis sense, Sun et al. (2006) reported that antioxidant enzymes
such as CAT, SOD and glutathione- S-transferase (GST) in ﬁsh
exposed to 0.05 mg/L phenanthrene, needed 14 days to recovertheir activity after an initial reduction.
The decrease of the effects observed in LPO between the
24 and 72 h samples can be also explained taking into accountthe MC depuration in ﬁsh. There is evidence that some aquaticorganisms, such as macrophytes, mollusks, crustacea, and ﬁsh,can accumulate and detoxify MCs in their tissues via the Phase IIdetoxication pathway ( Pﬂugmacher and Wiegand, 2001 ). These
studies showed the conversion of MCs in animal liver to a morepolar compound in correlation with a depletion of the glutathionepool of the cell by forming a MC-LR glutathione conjugate enzy-matically via soluble glutathione S-transferase ( Pﬂugmacher et
al., 1998 ).
The level of MCs detected in the liver of the exposed ﬁsh in
this study, higher at 24 h and none detected at 72 h post exposureagrees with the results obtained in the biochemical determina-tions, LPO and enzyme activities. There are also several studieson accumulation and depuration of MCs in ﬁsh and other aquaticorganisms that showed a decrease in MCs content in severalorgans (liver and muscle) in a time-dependent manner ( Williams
et al., 1997; Smith and Haney, 2006
).Mohamed and Hussein
(2006) reported that tilapia ﬁsh can depurate and excrete MCs
into the bile and surrounding water as a way to avoid toxicityfrom these hepatotoxins. Soares et al. (2004) found higher and
earlier MCs accumulation in liver compared to muscle, in whichthe highest accumulation occurred in the depuration period inexperiments performed in Tilapia rendalli . These ﬁndings could
be explained on the basis of two facts: ﬁrst, liver is the main organof detoxiﬁcation for ﬁsh and, second, since MCs mostly accu-mulate in ﬁsh liver ( Chen et al., 2006; Zhao et al., 2006 ), their
detoxiﬁcation starts there. In fact, accumulation studies of MCsin Nile tilapia in liver, muscle, gall bladder and spleen, demon-strated that about 90% of MCs were accumulated in the liver(Zhao et al., 2006 ).
Histopathological changes have also been reported to be
related with time, so that lesions caused by MCs can be recov-ered in ﬁsh. Thus, recovery of toxic histopathological effectscaused by MCs has been reported by Ernst et al. (2006) to occur
at 24–48 h in European whiteﬁsh ( C. lavaretus ).Li et al. (2005)
observed recovery of hepatocytes in bighead carp 48 h post-injection. Malbrouck et al. (2004) found recovery of the liver
structure and regeneration of hepatocytes 96 h post-injection ingoldﬁsh Carasius auratus as well as reconstruction of the tis-344 A.I. Prieto et al. / Aquatic T oxicology 84 (2007) 337–345
sue structure 21 days post-injection (of 125 mg/kg body weight
of MC-LR). In addition, time-dependent differences have beenreported in the antioxidant response to oxidative stress inducedby several chemicals in tilapia ( Basha and Rani, 2003; Peixoto
et al., 2006 ). Particularly MCs have been reported to produce
a biphasic response in GSH levels in mice and crabs ( Pinho
et al., 2005; Ding et al., 2000 ). Therefore, the initial recu-
peration observed in the ﬁsh exposed to cyanobacterial cellsafter 72 h, mainly in LPO and protein oxidation in the liver,could also be appreciable in the rest of the organs afterwards,because a longer time may be required for the de novo syn-thesis of proteins, once MCs have been depurated. However,more studies are required to illustrate the relation betweenthe toxic effects of MCs and the toxin concentration in ﬁshtissues.

Abstract 1 
Microcystins (MCs) induce oxidative stress in fish.  This study 2 
investigated the effect of vitamin E pre-treatment on MCs oxidative damage 3 
in liver, kidney and gills of tilapia fish ( Oreochromis niloticus ). Groups of fish 4 
were fed vitamin E supplements (200 or 700 mg/kg di et) for seven days, or 5 
received only commercial fish food, and then were e xposed to a single oral 6 
dose of cyanobacterial cells (120 µg/fish MC-LR) an d were sacrificed in 7 
24h. The potential benefits of vitamin E were evalu ated based on lipid 8 
peroxidation, protein oxidation, catalase (CAT), su peroxide dismutase 9 
(SOD), glutathione peroxidase (GPx), glutathione re ductase (GR) and 10 
GSH/GSSG levels. MCs induced a 1.6-fold increase in  LPO values in liver, 11 
whereas vitamin E pre-treated fish did not show any  alteration on this 12 
biomarker. Enzyme activities levels were also ameli orated by the 13 
chemoprotectant whereas protein oxidation and GSH/G SSG did not show 14 
any significant change. The highest vitamin E dose used showed to have 15 
the greater protective effects, particularly on the  biomarkers LPO and CAT 16 
activity. The results show that vit E could have a potential utility as 17 
preventive or therapeutic measure in MC-exposed fis h.  18

INTRODUCTION 2 
Cyanobacteria comprise an assemblage of prokaryotic  plantlike 3 
organisms that often dominate phytoplankton communi ties in warm, 4 
nutrient-enriched hard waters becoming their distri bution ubiquitous [1]. A 5 
potentially hazardous consequence of cyanobacterial  blooms is the 6 
production of different kind of toxins. Among cyano bacterial toxins, the 7 
hepatotoxins and specially microcystins (MCs) are a mong the most 8 
frequently observed and have been well studied [2].  9 
 10 
Although MCs are known hepatotoxic compounds, in fi sh they have 11 
been also reported to affect the kidney, gills, int estine, heart, etc. [3, 4]. 12 
These toxins are inhibitors of serine/threonin phos phatases, affecting 13 
intracellular signalling, cell growth, and differen tiation processes [5, 6]. In 14 
the pathogenesis of MCs toxicity, oxidative stress play also a significant 15 
role as many authors have already shown in differen t experimental models 16 
[7, 8, 9] including fish [10, 11, 12, 13]. 17 
 18 
Cellular oxidative stress is established when the p ro-oxidant forces 19 
overwhelm the antioxidant defences. Physiological a ntioxidant protection 20 
involves a variety of chemical systems, of endogeno us and exogenous 21 
origins, both water and fat-soluble. The endogenous  components include 22 
compounds such as NADH/NADPH, glutathione (GSH), pr otein sulphydryl 23 
(-SH) groups, uric acid and free radical scavenging  enzymes such as 24  7 
superoxide dismutase (SOD), catalase (CAT) and glut athione peroxidase 1 
(GPx) [14]. Exogenous dietary micronutrients such a s vitamins E and C as 2 
well as carotenoids also play important roles in th e antioxidant defence 3 
system. Additionally, more enzymes are needed for t he good working of 4 
this biochemical machinery such as glutathione redu ctase (GR), the 5 
enzyme reducing oxidized glutathione (GSSG) to its reduced state (GSH), 6 
or glucose-6-P-dehydrogenase that provides NADPH, e tc. 7 
These systems can prevent the formation of oxyradic als or intercept 8 
oxidative propagation reactions promoted by the oxy radicals once formed. 9 
Moreover, they protect cells against DNA strand bre aks, protein oxidation 10 
and lipid peroxidation (LPO). The latter may result  in loss of integrity of lipid 11 
membranes and generation of toxic aldehydes [14]. 12 
 13 
Vitamin E (vit E) is a generic descriptor for all m olecules that 14 
possesses the biological activity of α-tocopherol. Natural forms of vitamin E 15 
are all d-steroisomers and consist of a substituted  aromatic ring and a long 16 
isoprenoid side chain. There are eight naturally oc curring compounds with 17 
vit E activity, being α-tocopherol the one with the highest biopotency. Th is 18 
is a lipid-soluble antioxidant that can reduce lipi d peroxides, thereby 19 
protecting biological membranes from damage induced  by free radicals 20 
[15]. Tocher et al. [16] studied the effects of die tary vit E on antioxidant 21 
defence mechanisms of juvenile turbot ( Scophthalmus maximus  L.), halibut 22 
(Hippoglossus hippoglossus  L.) and sea bream ( Sparus aurata  L.), and 23 
observed that a decreased dietary vit E led to a ge nerally higher activities 24  8 
of the liver antioxidant enzymes and higher levels of lipid peroxides. Also 1 
Tocher et al. [17] in these fish species found that  vit E reduced the liver 2 
antioxidant defence enzyme activities previously in creased by feeding 3 
peroxidised oil. Similar results were found by Huan g and Huang [18] on 4 
juvenile hybrid tilapia fish subjected to the same oxidative insult, with a 5 
decrease in the level of thiobarbituric acid reacti ve substances (TBARS) 6 
and an increase of the tissue vitamin E and liver g lutathione level when 7 
dietary vit E increased. 8 
 9 
To the extent of our knowledge, the protective role  of vitamin E 10 
against the oxidative stress induced by MC in fish has not been previously 11 
investigated. In mice, different authors have appro ached this issue [19, 20, 12 
21, 22]. In aquatic organisms, in contrast, only Pi nho et al. [23] found that 13 
the pre-treatment with vitamin E modulated the anti oxidant responses after 14 
MCs exposure in gills of an estuarine crab species,  Chasmagnathus 15 
granulatus . 16 
 17 
In view of these reports, this study was undertaken  to determine the 18 
effects of a pre-treatment with two different doses  of Trolox, a commercial 19 
name for a water soluble vitamin E analog, on the o xidative stress induced 20 
by MCs by oral route in tilapia fish. This was done  by analysing the 21 
responses of different enzymatic activities such as  CAT, SOD, GPx and GR 22 
as well as lipid peroxidation in liver, kidney and gills. Moreover, GSH/GSSG 23  9 
ratio and protein oxidation by means of protein car bonyl content were 1 
determined in liver.  2

MATERIALS AND METHODS 5 
Chemicals 6 
Vitamine E, as Trolox, 6-hydroxy-2,5,7,8-tetramethy lchroman-2-carboxylic 7 
acid, was obtained from Aldrich. Microcystin standa rds were supplied by 8 
Cyanobiotech (Germany) with a purity of 95-99%. Oth er chemicals used 9 
were purchased in Merck and Sigma. 10

Experimental setup and acclimation of fish 12 
48 male Oreochromis niloticus sp. (Nile tilapia, Perciformes: 13 
Cichlidae) , average weight 50 ± 8 g, were obtained from a fis h hatchery in 14 
Córdoba. Tilapia is one of the major farmed fish sp ecies on the global scale 15 
[18] and also has been extensively employed to stud y the antioxidant 16 
response to many toxic substances. Fish were transf erred to the laboratory 17 
where they were held in six aquaria (8 individuals/ aquarium) with 96 L of 18 
fresh water. Exposure to chlorine was minimized by filling the tanks at least 19 
3 days before the fish were introduced. The aquariu ms were also set up 20 
with continuous system of water filtration and aera tion (Eheim Liberty 150 21 
and Bio-Espumador cartridges (Bio-Espumador) and th e temperature 22 
varied between 19 and 23ºC. Dissolved oxygen values  were maintained 23 
between 6.5 and 7.5 mg/L. Mean values for additiona l parameters of water 24  10  
quality were: pH 7.6 ± 0.3, conductivity 287 µS/cm, Ca 2+  0.60 mM and Mg 2+  1 
0.3 mM. Fish were fed with commercial fish food and  were acclimatized for 2 
15 days before the beginning of the experiments. 3 
 4 
Collection of Microcystis aeruginosa  strain culture and determination of 5 
cyanobacterial toxins 6 
Lyophilized M. aeruginosa  isolated strain culture was kindly supplied 7 
by Dra Susana Franca (Lisboa, Portugal). MCs contai ned were extracted 8 
from dried cell material using the method of Moreno  et al. [24]. The 9 
lyophilized cells (50 mg) were extracted three time s with 10 mL 0.1 M 10 
acetic acid and 20 mL of a mixture of methanol:chlo roform (1:1 v/v). The 11 
cell suspension was sonicated in an ultra-sound bat h for 15 minutes, stirred 12 
for 30 minutes at room temperature, and then centri fuged at 4500 g for 15 13 
minutes. The upper aqueous phases were combined and  concentrated in a 14 
rotary evaporator. The residue was resuspended in 0 .5 mL methanol for 15 
chromatographic separation.  16 
The LC system used to analyse the toxin contents wa s a Varian 17 
9012 equipped with a Varian ProStar 330 Diode Array  Detector. 18 
Chromatographic data were processed with a Star Chr omatography 19 
Workstation (Varian Technologies). Chromatographic separation of MCs 20 
was performed according to Moreno et al. [24] on a 250 mm x 4.6 mm i.d., 21 
5 µm, LiChrosphere C18 column purchased from Merck (Darmstadt, 22 
Germany).  23  11  
Standard solutions of microcystins MC-LR, MC-YR and  MC-RR 1 
were prepared in  methanol (500 µg/mL) and diluted as required with 2 
methanol for use as working solutions (0.5-5.0 mg/L  of each toxin). Only 3 
MC-LR was identified in the cyanobacterial cell ext racts analysed and the 4 
peak area of the MC-LR standard solution was applie d for quantification. 5 
The concentrations of MCs obtained from lyophilised  cells were 1350 µg/g 6 
MC-LR.  7 
 8 
Exposure 9 
Fish in aquaria 1 and 2 (n=8) were fed daily with c ommercial fish 10 
food for 7 days (Table 1). Fish from aquarium 1 wer e not exposed to MCs 11 
and were used as controls. The 7 th  day, fish in aquarium 2 received a single 12 
dose of cyanobacterial cells dosing approximately 1 20 µg MC-LR/fish 13 
(determined from HPLC analysis) in the diet, with t he commercial fish food. 14 
After the toxin administration both groups of fish were sacrificed in 24 h. 15 
 16 
Tilapia fish in aquaria 3 and 4 (n=8) were fed dail y with commercial 17 
fish food plus 200 mg vit E/kg diet, equivalent to 0.06 mg vit E/fish/day for 7 18 
days. The last day, fish in aquarium 4 were also ex posed to the same dose 19 
of cyanobacterial cells (120 µg MC-LR/fish) in the diet, whereas fish in 20 
aquarium 3 did not receive the toxin and were used as controls. 24 hours 21 
after the toxin application fish were sacrificed. 22  12  
Fish in aquaria 5 and 6 (n=8) were subjected to the  same treatment 1 
as previously described, but using a higher dose of  vit E, 700 mg vit E/kg 2 
diet, equivalent to 0.21 mg vit E/fish/day. 3 
Both doses of vit E were selected in based to a rep ort by Huang et 4 
al. [25], who studied how a dietary supplementation  of 0. 50, 100, 200, 450 5 
and 700 mg vit E/kg diet for 14 weeks, affected asc orbate induced iron- 6 
catalyzed tissue lipid peroxidation of hybrid tilap ia. They observed that in 7 
liver, TBARS values appeared to decrease with incre asing vit E up to 200 8 
mg/kg diet. Moreover, no toxic effects due to the v it E supplementation 9 
were observed. 10 
 11 
Fish were fed by manually crushing mixture of the d ifferent 12 
components (fish food, toxic cyanobacterial cells, and vit E, depending on 13 
the treatment) in a mortar followed by sonication. This procedure resulted in 14 
small sticky pellets and was designed to replicate the type of exposure that 15 
may occur when a bloom of cyanobacteria undergoes l ysis under field 16 
conditions releasing its MCs contents. The pellets were placed in the tank 17 
and drifted to the bottom for the fish to take. It was ensured that all the 18 
pellets were eaten within an hour. The amount of co mmercial fish food 19 
administered per fish was 0.3 g/day. 20

Preparation of postmitochondrial supernatant (PMS) 22 
At the end of the experiment, the fish were anaesth etized by 23 
immersion in 50 mg/L tricaine methane sulphonate (M S-222) solution for 5- 24  13  
10 min before they were killed by transection of th e spinal cord. All 1 
experimental groups of fish were anaesthetized in t he same manner what 2 
excludes a specific effect of the product in the st ress-related research. The 3 
liver, kidney and gills were removed, weighed, rins ed with ice-cold saline 4 
and kept at -85°C until analysis. The tissues were homogenized in chilled 5 
TRIS buffer (100 mM, pH 7.8; 1:10 w/v) using an Ult ra-Turrax® tissue 6 
homogenizer. The homogenates were centrifuged at 10 500 g for 20 min at 7 
4°C to obtain the post-mitochondrial supernatant (P MS) for various 8 
biochemical analyses. 9 
 10 
Lipid peroxidation 11 
Lipid peroxidation products were quantified by the thiobarbituric acid 12 
(TBA) method [26]. End lipid peroxidation products react with TBA reagent 13 
under acidic conditions to generate a pink coloured  product. Briefly, the 14 
homogenized tissue (0.5 mL), previously treated wit h 25 µL of 15 
butylhydroxytoluene 1% mass/vol in glacial acetic, was mixed with 0.2 mL 16 
of sodium laurylsulphate (8%), 1 mL of acetic acid (20% vol/vol) and 1 mL 17 
of 0.8% thiobarbituric acid. This mixture was then heated at 95ºC for 30 18 
min. The resulting chromogen was extracted with 3 m L of n-butyl alcohol 19 
and, after centrifugation (1500g for 10 min), the a bsorbance of the organic 20 
phase was determined at 532 nm. 1,1,3,3-tetramethox ypropan was used as 21 
a standard. Values were presented as nmol TBARS /g tissue. 22 
 23 
Protein carbonyl content 24  14  
We followed the method described by Levine et al. [ 27]. Briefly, two 1 
test tubes of 1.0 mL containing 30 and 60 µL homoge nized sample 2 
respectively ( ≈10-20 mg protein) were taken. 0.5 mL of fresh 10 mM  2,4- 3 
dinitrophenylhydrazine (DNPH) prepared in 2 M HCl w as added to the 4 
tubes, and the contents were mixed thoroughly and i ncubated at room 5 
temperature for 1 hour. The tubes were shaken inter mittently every 15 6 
minutes. Then 0.5 mL of 20% TCA (w/v) was added to both tubes that were 7 
centrifuged at 11,000g for 3 min to obtain the prot ein pellet. The 8 
supernatant was carefully aspirated and discarded. Finally the precipitates 9 
were washed three times with 0.5 mL of ethanol: eth yl acetate (1:1, v/v) to 10 
remove unreacted DNPH and lipid remnants. The final  protein pellet was 11 
dissolved in 0.6 mL of 6 M guanidine hydrochloride and incubated overnight 12 
at room temperature. The insoluble materials were r emoved by 13 
centrifugation and the supernatant were measured sp ectrophotometrically 14 
at 366 nm. Results are expressed as nmol carbonyl/m g protein, using the 15 
extinction coefficient 22,000 M-1 cm -1. 16 
 17 
Antioxidant enzymes 18 
The catalase (CAT; EC 1.11.1.6) activity assay, con sisting in the 19 
spectrophotometric measurement of H 2O2 breakdown at 240 nm was 20 
assayed following the method of Beers and Sizer [28 ]. The assay mixture 21 
contained 0.3 mL phosphate buffer saline (PBS), 2.0 7 mL H 2O, 30 µL 22 
homogenized tissue and 0.6 mL H 2O2 10 mM. The final concentrations in 23  15  
the cuvettes were 50 mM potassium phosphate (pH 7),  20 mM H 2O2 and 1 
homogenized tissue (30 µL).  2

Total superoxide dismutase (SOD; EC 1.15.1.1) activ ity was 4

DISCUSSION 23 
Oxidative stress is one of the mechanisms implicate d in MCs pathogenicity 24 
in fish [10, 11, 12, 13, 33]. Li et al. [10] showed  that MCs increase the 25  20  
reactive oxidative species (ROS) generation and pro duce subsequent 1 
changes in the enzymatic and not enzymatic antioxid ant defence in 2 
hepatocytes of common carp Cyprinus carpio . Moreover, ROS induce loss 3 
of mitochondrial membrane potential, mitochondria p ermeability, transition 4 
and activation of calpain, and Ca2+ calmodulin-depe ndent protein kinase 5 
11 all of which are step towards apoptosis [7, 34].  Formation of superoxide 6 
radical was followed first by altered cytoskeleton structures, then by LDH 7 
leakage. Lysosomes are particularly prone to damage  by hydrogen 8 
peroxide and this damage has to be considered an ea rly trigger for the 9 
degeneration of cells upon exposure to MCYST-LR [35 ]. 10 
 11 
Fish response to this oxidative insult varies from depletion of the 12 
enzyme proteins to an increase in their activity, d epending on the MCs 13 
dose, exposure route, fish species, etc. In this se nse, Jos et al. [11] showed 14 
that the daily oral exposure to cyanobacterial mate rial containing 60g MC- 15 
LR/fish/day for 14 and 21 days resulted in an adapt ative response in tilapia 16 
fish, with increased activities of the antioxidant enzymes and higher LPO 17 
levels. However, the oral administration of a singl e dose equivalent to 120g 18 
MC-LR/fish produces a decrease in the enzymatic act ivities in tilapia fish 19 
sacrificed 24h post exposure [33], as well as incre ased LPO values. In the 20 
present study, the same dose of toxin has produced similar effects on LPO, 21 
a general decrease in the activity of the enzymes s tudied in kidney and 22 
gills, but an increase has been observed in liver. These results may be 23 
explained because the liver contains the largest de fence system what 24 
prevents this organ from suffering more intense dam ages.  25  21  
 1 
Vitamin E is an important antioxidant involved in t he protection of 2 
membranes from oxidative damage. Dietary vit E requ irement of tilapia is 3 
dependent on several factors such as the dietary li pid level, degree of 4 
unsaturation of dietary lipid source, the oxidative  status of the dietary lipid, 5 
the presence of other antioxidants, etc. [25, 36]. Both doses of vit E have 6 
shown to have a protective effect on LPO values in all the organs studied. 7 
Vit E stops the chain reaction mechanism of lipid p eroxidation, presumably 8 
via its ability to quench free radicals. Its anti-o xidant activity is based on the 9 
ease with which the hydrogen on the hydroxyl group of the chroman ring 10 
can be donated to neutralize a lipid peroxyl radica l (LOO˙), creating a more 11 
stabile tocopheroxyl radical [37]. This can be redu ced (restored) to 12 
tocopherol directly by ubiquinol or vitamin C, and then by glutathione or 13 
lipoic acid (via vitamin C). The positive influence  of vit E on this biomarker 14 
has also been reported by Gehringer et al. [20], wh o observed reduced 15 
LPO values in mice intraperitoneally exposed to MC- LR extracts when they 16 
were fed vit E supplements. 17 
 18 
The protective role of vit E on protein oxidation i n liver has been not 19 
so clear. Reports about the influence of this chemo protectant on this 20 
parameter in fish are scarce. Passi et al. [38], su ggest that in freshwater 21 
and marine fish, lipid peroxidation and accumulatio n of oxidized proteins 22 
during aging are likely linked with an age-dependen t decline of vitamin C 23 
and lipophilic antioxidants (such as vit E) content s in muscle tissue. In 24  22  
mammalian models, however, the benefits of vit E su pplementation on this 1 
parameter are better known [39], although no studie s have been performed 2 
considering a MC exposure.  3 
 4 
Vit E ameliorate CAT activity levels in all the org ans studied 5 
showing a dose-dependent influence mainly in the li ver and the kidney. 6 
With the lower dose there is not enzyme destruction  but a defensive 7 
response in the kidney, whereas in the liver this e nzyme activity increased 8 
in a lesser extent. These results agree with Pinho et al., [23] who have also 9 
reported that the pre-treatment of the estuarine cr ab ( Chasmagnathus 10 
granulatus ) with 600 mg/kg vit E, was effective in reducing c atalase activity 11 
in posterior gills.  12 
 13 
Vit E has also shown to protect SOD activity, mainl y in the liver, 14 
GPx and GR activities. The beneficial effects of th is chemoprotectant on 15 
CAT, SOD, and GPx activities could be explained due  to its role as free 16 
radical scavenger. Venkasteswara et al. [40] observ ed that nickel and 17 
chromium treatment to mice resulted in a significan t decline of SOD activity. 18 
In contrast, a supplementation with 2 mg/kg vit E w ith NiCl 2+K 2Cr 2O7 19 
exerted no significant alterations in the liver ant ioxidant systems as 20 
compared to control, thus indicating its ameliorati ve role. 21 
 22 
Regarding to the influence of vit E pre-treatment o n the GSH/GSSG 23 
ratio, Pinho et al. [23] found an increase of nonpr oteic sulfhydrils (NP-SH) 24  23  
concentration in gills of crabs preexposed to vit E  and not exposed to MC in 1 
comparison to crabs from the control group not pret reated with the vitamin 2 
and sacrificed two days after the exposure. However , in fish sacrificed after 3 
7 days no changes were observed. In the present stu dy, the lack of 4 
changes on the GSH/GSSG levels agrees with the resu lts obtained in the 5 
GR activity in liver, where no alterations were obs erved. GR is an important 6 
enzyme that maintains the GSH/GSSG homeostasis unde r stress 7 
conditions [14] regenerating GSH through the reduct ion of GSSG into GSH. 8 
Moreover, the levels of GSH could be related with G Px activity, because 9 
this enzyme catalyzes the reduction of hydrogen per oxide into water or 10 
organic peroxides to their corresponding stable alc ohols by oxidizing the 11 
GSH into its oxidized form GSSG. The protective eff ect of both doses of vit 12 
E on GPx activity could explain the lack of signifi cant changes found in 13 
GSH/GSSG levels. 14 
 15 
Other authors have shown the influence of a vit E p re-treatment on 16 
a MC induced oxidative damage on different biomarke rs. Pinho et al. [23] 17 
found increased GST activity in crabs exposed to MC s, values that were 18 
reduced with vit E pre-treatment. However, Gehringe r et al. [20] observed 19 
decreased GST levels in MC intoxicated mice, and a significant reduction of 20 
this toxin-induced decrease when mice received vit E supplementation. 21 
Additionally, they reported a protection of the liv er damage, reflected in a 22 
significant reduction in the levels of serum alanin e transaminase, found 23 
also by Al-Jassabi and Khalil [21], as well as an i ncrease in the time to 24  24  
death. This agrees with the results of Hermansky et  al. [19], who found that 1 
vit E produced a significant protection from lethal ity in MC exposed mice. 2 
Moreover, Weng et al. [22] have shown that vit E si gnificantly reduces the 3 
generation of ROS and effectively inhibits the MC-L R-induced hepatocyte 4 
apoptosis and liver injury in mice. MC induced oxid ative stress not only 5 
affects proteins and lipids but also produces DNA d amage. Vit E has shown 6 
to inhibit the formation of 8-hydroxydeoxyguanosine  (8-OH-dG), a 7 
biomarker relevant to carcinogenesis, in a concentr ation-dependent 8 
manner in liver of MC exposed mice [21]. As far as we know this is the first 9 
study that investigates the effects of a supplement ation of vit E on oxidative 10 
biomarkers such as SOD, GPx, GR activities and prot ein oxidation after MC 11 
exposure. 12 
 13 
The scientific literature shows that most of the st udies dealing with 14 
the protective effects of vit E on MC induced toxic ity are performed in 15 
mammalian models. However, fish and other aquatic o rganisms are 16 
naturally exposed to MC, in their own environments or in aquaculture 17 
facilities, and it would be of big importance to fu rther investigate in this area 18 
to establish the potential utility of chemoprotecta nts such as vit E as 19 
preventive or therapeutic measures in case of fish that live or are cultivated 20 
in waters chronically contaminated with MC. 21 
 22 
 In conclusion, vit E pre-treatment ameliorates the  levels of oxidative 23 
stress biomarkers altered by the oral exposure to c yanobacterial cells in 24  25  
Tilapia fish. The highest protective effects are pr oduced with 700 mg vit 1 
E/kg diet as results in LPO levels and CAT activity  show. This study 2 
advances new insights on the influence of vit E in some biochemical 3 
parameters in MC exposed tilapia. A practical appli cation of the present 4 
data could be the possible preventive or therapeuti c use of vit E against 5 
MC-induced toxicity in fish. 6
